abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Schizophrenia is a chronic and severe mental disorder, and it has been predicted to be highly polygenic. Common SNPs located in or near <jats:italic>BNIP3L</jats:italic> were found to be genome-wide significantly associated with schizophrenia in recent genome-wide association studies. The purpose of our study is to investigate potential causal variants in <jats:italic>BNIP3L</jats:italic> gene.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>We performed targeted sequencing for all exons and un-translated regions of <jats:italic>BNIP3L</jats:italic> gene among 1806 patients with schizophrenia and 998 healthy controls of Han Chinese origin. Three rare nonsynonymous mutations, <jats:italic>BNIP3L</jats:italic> (NM_004331): c.52A>G, c.167G>A and c.313A>T, were identified in schizophrenia cases, and two of them were newly reported. The frequencies of these rare nonsynonymous mutations were significantly different between schizophrenia cases and healthy controls. For the common variants, rs147389989 achieved significance in both allelic and genotypic distributions with schizophrenia. Rs1042992 and rs17310286 were significantly associated with schizophrenia in meta-analyses using PGC, CLOZUK, and our new datasets in this study.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Our findings provided further evidence that <jats:italic>BNIP3L</jats:italic> gene is a susceptibility gene of schizophrenia and revealed functional and potential causal mutations in <jats:italic>BNIP3L</jats:italic>. However, more functional validations are suggested to better understand the role of <jats:italic>BNIP3L</jats:italic> in the etiology of schizophrenia.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: All participants signed informed consent, and the study was approved by the ethical committee of Bio-X Institutes, Shanghai Jiao Tong University. The reference number is 20190918.

assertion.value: The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
